NOIAN OCEAN
FAM-18, the Southern route across the Atlantic, was inaugurated
by Pan American Airways from New York very hurriedly on May 20,
1939,
United States could claim the honor
establishing the first regular air service across the Atlantic.
Special 30-cent transatlantic stamp was issued for first flight
covers. The route went via Horta, in the Azores, to Lisbon and
to Marseilles.
©

June 8, 1939.
FIRST FLIGHT COVER SERVICE
VIA THE NORTH TRANSATIAITIC AIR MAIL SERVICE
The United States Post Office Department has announced the inauguration
of Air Mall Service over the Morthern route of the Transatlantic Air Mail Service
from New York, N. Y. to Southampton, England,
Newfoundland; and Foynes, Ireland.
via Shediac, Now Brunswick; Botwood,
In view of the possible difficulties which my be encountored by Phil-
atelists or Collectors in the United States or other
• countries in securing first
flight covers to be posted and carriod on the first flight of this service fros
New Brunswick, Nonfoundland, Ireland or England to other points, Pan American
Airways offers
¡vo cooporave as 10 onS:
SERVICE BY PAN AMERICAN AIRMAYS
Pan Amorican Airways will accept at Its Now York Offico, consignment of
first flight covers to bo posted and carriod on the first flight of the forthern
Route of the Transatlantic Air Mail Service.
All covers for the service must be
forwarded in a semarate container to Philatelic Scetion, Pan American Airways,
135 B..
42nd St.
These consieneons o! covoss : must be accompanica by money order
or certified checks, made payable to Pan American Airuys, Now York, N.Y. for
the total amount of service desirod by the sender, at the prices quoted bolon.
It is also requested that the sender include with the covers an itemized list
of the services desired.
SERVICE AVAILABLE, PREPARATION OF COVER, CLOSING TINE FOR COVERS
Senders may address their covers to thenselves or other persons in the
United States or elsewhore.

POSTAGE STAMPS CANNOT BE ACCEPTED IN PATIENT FOR THESE SERVICES.
SPECIAL CONDITIONS
1. It must be clearly understood by all who avail themselves of this
service that the offer of Pan American Airmys is limited to accepting consign-
ments of covers in the United States, forwarding them to points where sender
desires same posted, in accordance with his endorsemcht on cover, and deposit-
ing the covers in the local post office before the closing time for this mail,
as fixed by the local post office. Acceptance by the Company in New York of
thesc covers does not constitute a guarantee that the covers will be carried
on the first flight.
Covers arriving too late to be servicod will be returned
to sender. In the event that the Company forvards the covers from New York
to the point where they are to be posted, but due to any circunstances arrive
too late at the points to be serviced on the first flight, they will bo re-
times to
the sender with a refund of the amount received, less a handling
charge of 15€ per cover.
2. Round trip covers cannot be accepted or serviced. Only individual
covers from one point to another will be serviced by the Compary.
Pen American
Airways also gives notice that it cannot fix special stamps or blocks of stamps
on covers, to meet the wishes of collectors,
Authorized foreign stamps on the covers.
but will affix only the regular
Covers with foroign postage already
affixed on the covers by the senders cannot be accepted by the Company.
nose
covers should be sent direct by the sender to the Post Ulice where same are to
be posted. Requests for crew autographs on the covers will not be considered
granted.
Covers to be posted in the United States and destined to New Brunswick,
Newfoundland, Ireland or England must not be sent to the Company.
These covers
must be forwarded to the Postmaster, New York, N.I., under cover specifically
requesting that they be held for the first North Transatlantic Air lil Service.
vor rates and other details of this service consult your local Postmaster.
4. The Newfoundland and British Postal Adninistretions have advised that
no cachet will be affixed on covers posted at their offices. Pan Amorican Air-
ways will endeavor to affix a special commemorative cachet on all covers han-
dled by the Company from these points. The British Post Office also gives
notice that it will not backstamp covers arriving there. All other Postal
Administrations indicate they will back stamp covers.

IMPORTANT
5. Covers intended for ultimate delivery to points beyond Newfoundland
